results.name: Aeschynite-(Nd)
results.description_short: Forms as tabular and prismatic crystals, up to several mm, and as equigranular and radiating crystal clusters, or massive.
results.tlform: as tabular and prismatic crystals to several mm, as equigranular and radiating clusters, also massive
results.occurrence: veins in slate and metamorphosed dolostone
results.otheroccurrence: In veins in slate and metamorphosed dolostone.
results.colour: Dark to pale brown, brownish black
results.aboutname: For its relationship to <M>Aeschynite-(Ce)</M>, with Neodymium as the dominant rare-earth element.
results.other:
Radioactive.
The mineral is readily soluble in warm HCl,
H2SO4, H3PO4 and weakly in HNO3.
results.commentcolor: yellowish orange to reddish orange in thin section; dark grey in reflected light.

results.name: Agardite-(Nd)
results.description_short:
Originally an incompletely characterised member of the Mixite Group, published without approval. 

Finally approved in 2010, based on material from the Hilarion Mine, Lavrion, Greece.

Quantitative analyses are generally needed to ensure that the M...
results.tlform: Thin, acicular to hair-like crystals up to 0.5 mm long and up to 5 μm thick, elongate along [001], with a hexagonal cross section. Also occurs with agardite-(Y) and/or agardite-(La) to form rims, up to 3 μm thick, in zoned acicular crystals, up to 0.015 × 1.2 mm, with a core of zálesíite. Typically in sprays or radiating clusters up to 2 mm.
results.occurrence: In cavities of an oxidized ore (primarily goethite) and in cracks of supergene altered mica schist.
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: O = pale turquoise; E = bright green-blue.
results.type_specimen_store: Fersman Mineralogical Museum of Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, number 4020/1.
results.commentluster: Vitreous in crystals and silky in aggregates.

results.name: Astrocyanite-(Ce)
results.aboutname: From the Greek άστρον ("astron") for "star", κυανός ("kyanos") for "blue", in allusion to its colour and habit of the aggregates, and the dominant lanthanide element in its composition.
results.other: Soluble with effervescence in dilute HCl.
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: Strongly pleochroic from bright blue to pale blue, almost colorless.
results.type_specimen_store: Institut royal des Sciences naturalles de Belgique, Brussels, Belgium.
results.commentcrystal: <mi>space group P6/mmm, P6mm, P622, P_62m or P_6m2</mi>

results.name: Calcioancylite-(Nd)
results.description_short:
The Nd analogue of calcioancylite-(Ce) and calcioancylite-(La). 
The Ca analogue of gysinite-(Nd).
results.tlform: Small pine-cone-like aggregate of crystals up to 1 mm long. Characterized by a bipyramidal pseudorhombic habit.
results.occurrence: In a miarolitic cavity in granite.
results.aboutname: Named for the relationship to the previously described calcioancylite-(Ce), with neodymium being the dominant REE. The root name is from the Greek αγκυλός ("ankylos") for "curved", in allusion to its usually rounded and distorted crystal shapes, and the prefix "CALCIO-" in alluion to its composition with CALCIum dominant over strontium.
results.type_specimen_store: Municipal Natural History Museum, Milan, Italy, M29872.

results.name: Cervandonite-(Ce)
results.tlform: Black, rosettelike aggregates up to 4 mm in diameter.
results.aboutname: Named in 1988 by T. Armbruster, C. Bühler, S. Graeser, H.A. Stalder, and G. Amthauer for the type locality at Pizzo Cervandone, a mountain ridge along the Italian-Swiss border.  The suffix/modifier indicates the species has essential REE, predominantly cerium.
results.opticalcomments: Refractive indices are ~1.99 parallel to a direction in which the grain is yellowish, reddish brown, and ~2.0 where black.
results.type_specimen_store:
Naturhistorisches Museum, Basel, Switzerland, number M30802 (holotype).
Naturhistorisches Museum, Bern, Switzerland, numbers B3953 and B4695 (cotype, Italy).
Naturhistorisches Museum, Bern, Switzerland, number B4880 (cotype, Switzerland)

results.name: Clinofergusonite-(Nd)
results.tlform: Irregular grains and rarely prismatic and bipyramidal, (0.02-0.06 mm, max. 0.25 mm).
results.occurrence: In a niobium-rare earth deposit in a proterozoic riebeckitized dolomite.
results.aboutname: Originally named fergusonite-β-(Nd) in allusion to its dimorphous relation to <m>fergusonite-(Nd)</m>. Renamed to clinofergusonite-(Nd) in 2022 by the IMA, where 'clino' indicates that the species is monoclinic.  The root name honors Robert Ferguson (8 September 1769 – 3 December 1840, London, England) of Raith, Scottish landowner, politician and mineral collector.

results.name: Florencite-(Nd)
results.tlform: Pulverulent earthy material in which individual crystals cannot be distinguished with a microscope.
results.occurrence: In the weathered zone, on fracture surfaces, in chert.
results.aboutname: Named for its relationship to florencite (now <M>florencite-(Ce)</M>). The root name florencite is in honour of Dr. Guilherme (William) Florence (19 June 1864 - 5 October 1942), Brazilian mineralogist with the São Paulo Geographic and Geological Commission. He made a preliminary chemical examination of the mineral. The "-(Nd)" suffix was added in 1987 (Nickel and Mandarino), in allusion to neodymium being the dominant REE in the composition.

results.name: Françoisite-(Nd)
results.aboutname: Named in 1988 by P. Piret, M. Deliens, and J. Piret-Meunier in honor of Dr. Armand François (Aljustrel, Portugal, December 28th 1922 - ), Belgian geologist and former director of the Geology Department of Gécamine, a Zaïrian mining company.
results.type_specimen_store: Royal Belgian Institute of Natural Sciences, Brussels

results.name: Gadolinite-(Ce)
results.mindat_formula_note: Often slightly radioactive due to minor U and/or Th contents; therefore often metamict.
results.description_short:
The cerium analogue of Gadolinite-(Y) and  Gadolinite-(Nd).
At the type locality, gadolinite-(Ce) often occurs with an orange or yellow alteration rim (up to 0.5 mm).

The Italian occurrences of gadolinite-(Ce) are not probed by analyses and most co...
results.tlform: Black irregular masses up to 20 mm in matrix.
results.aboutname: Named for its relationship to gadolinite-(Y), but with cerium as the dominant rare earth element.  Gadolinite honors Johan Gadolin (5 June 1760, Turku, Finland - 15 August 1852, Mynämäki, Finland), chemist, physicist, and mineralogist.
results.opticalcomments:
The mineral is reported in numerous sources as "isotropic" with n = 1.78, but as the mineral is monoclinic, this observation was clearly done on metamict material. This assertion appears to derive from an observation on material only from Skien, Norway (Segalstad & Larsen, 1978). In contrast to the Norwegian sample, gadolinite-(Ce) from the Malmkärra mine, Norberg, Sweden is U-free and Th-free and is non-metamict. This material shows normal anisotropic optical properties consistent with a monoclinic symmetry (non-zero birefringence; biaxial nature).

Note that in the absence of measured R.I. data for anisotropic gadolinite-(Ce), the listed R.I. values above are those of the analogous species gadolinite-(Nd) (but no estimate of errors is attempted). However, these values nonetheless successfully reproduce the observed birefringence and 2V° of the Malmkärra mine gadolinite-(Ce). Not unexpectedly, the overall optical properties of non-metamict gadolinite-(Ce) appear to be largely comparable to those of gadolinite-(Nd).
results.type_specimen_store: Mineralogical-Geological Museum, University of Oslo, Oslo, Norway, number 21325.
results.thermalbehaviour: DTA shows a broad and indistinct exotherm at about 250-350 °C and a large exotherm at 790 °C grading into a smaller exotherm at 8l0 °C.
results.commentcrystal: Space group P2/c was determined for material heated at 700<sup>o</sup>C

results.name: Gysinite-(Nd)
results.description_short: The lead analogue of calcioancylite-(Nd). The Nd analogue of gysinite-(La) and gysinite-(Ce).
results.aboutname: Named in honor of Marcel Gysin (1891–1974), Professor of Mineralogy, University of Geneva, who worked for several years in the Shaba Province of Zaire, where this mineral originated.
results.other: Soluble with effervescence in cold dilute hydrochloric acid.
results.type_specimen_store: Department of Mineralogy, Geneva Natural History Museum
